text: The noon sunlight filters through gaps in the clouds, spilling onto the inn’s signboard as dust drifts slowly in the golden beams.
Outside, a layer of snow has melted away, leaving the stone-paved street damp. The air carries the scent of fresh bread and simmering stew.
I toss the broken wood from this morning’s chaos into the fire pit in the backyard. The flames crackle as heat rises in waves.
The rare calm of the day almost makes one forget last night’s storm and noise.
But I didn’t expect her to return.
The doorbell rings softly.

Alicia steps inside, frost still clinging to her armor. Behind her follows a young girl, chestnut hair tied in short braids, lively eyes shining. She carries a basket filled with bottles of different colors, like droplets of dew sealed by light.
“Innkeeper, I brought you a few small things today. Healing potions and antidotes. I heard you often get drunkards injuring themselves here.”
I blink in surprise. Before I can respond, the girl has already run to the counter, curiously looking around the room.
“Master, this place is so quiet—and really warm.”
“It doesn’t feel like an inn. It feels like home.”
“Lucia, don’t say such things.”
“It’s fine. She’s not wrong. This place has been a little too quiet lately.”
I set down the rag in my hand and glance out at the street through the window.
“There used to be merchant caravans passing by every day. Now you can wait all day without seeing a single one.”
“They say monsters have reappeared in the northern forest.” I pause. “Several patrols have gone missing. Even the Church won’t go near it.”
“Are there really monsters? I thought it was just a rumor.”
“Rumors usually have some truth at their root. When we passed nearby, I felt something was wrong with the forest air… it smelled like rust.”
“You noticed it too?”
“Yes. The wind carried the scent of rust. Like blood.”
“I actually thought it smelled kind of nice.”
“That just means you’re still a child.”
Watching their natural interaction, a strange sense of reassurance wells up inside me—perhaps in this chaotic world, laughter like this is the rarest treasure of all.
“I made this one myself! You won’t get drunk or have a headache, but it tastes really good! Want to try it, big brother?”
As she speaks, Lucia pulls out a small bottle from her basket. The cork nearly pops off, and a sweet fragrance immediately fills the air.
“Smell it—it’s mixed with honey and strawberries.” She excitedly holds the bottle up to me.
Caught off guard by the scent, I chuckle. “It actually smells pretty good.”
“If you don’t want to end up sleeping under the counter for three days, don’t drink it.”
“That won’t happen!” She puffs her cheeks, looking serious.
“The last time she tested her potion, she slept for three days.”
“That was an experimental accident!”
Their banter feels like a fresh breeze, sweeping away the gloom that lingered from the morning.
I suddenly realize that ever since she stepped into the inn, the air itself has felt different—like sunlight melting a river long frozen.

Option B: Tease, “So, are you two going to share one room?”
